posts.cooked: Passkeys are starting to get rolled out by Google, Apple, and Microsoft. It would be a massive security boost to implement this new standard (likely to work with a future cloud backup option).

link_counts.title: "Ideas" category in addition to feature requests?

posts.cooked: Implement passkeys for what?

posts.name: ğŸ‘ŠğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ğŸ”¥
posts.cooked:
Avitus:

(likely to work with a future cloud backup option).

Passkeys were created to strengthen and simplify authentication, I donâ€™t see a benefit for encrypting backups as opposed to a long password. Moreover, the private portion of passkeys are currently backed up to Apple and Google password manager, whose security design is similar to Signal SVR, so if Signal wanted to offer encrypted cloud backups, they could have already stored a backup encryption key in their password manager. Passkeys donâ€™t improve on that.

posts.name: Jordan Winch
posts.cooked:
Passkeys only real use case in Signal is as an alternative to SMS verification, or as an alternative to Signalâ€™s pins. Signal could do encrypted online backups currently by encrypting your backup with your Pin but there are a lot of issues with that, but the biggest problem with Cloud backups is the sheer cost of backing up files, there is a reason that WhatsApp uses iCloud and Google Drive for backups.

As for using Passkeys as an alternative for SMS verification, I think this is a cool idea but SMS verification will still have to exist making Passkey a bit of a useless, and unnecessary complexity. If Passkey is used to replace SMS verification then I would be interested, however this would probably have to be a complete replacement of Phone numbers which would have its own set of complexities and problems.

posts.name: ğŸ‘ŠğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ğŸ”¥
posts.cooked: Whatsapp is multi-platform so it makes sense.

As of now there would be no tangible security or usability benefit to this. Signal keeps as little user data as possible on their side and thatâ€™s what makes it a secure alternative to every other messaging app so I donâ€™t see that changing. Maybe this could be a replacement for the PIN but that seems like a very complex thing to implement to replace something with as simple of a use case as with the PIN.

I want my messages to be my responsibility and Signal stands by that so I donâ€™t think Signal will ever implement a cloud backup option. The only use case for this could be syncing message histories between desktop or new devices but a QR code is already enough for that.

There could be a slight use case for this if Signal ever implements syncing the entire chat history across authorized devices but that needs to be implemented first.

posts.name: ğŸ‘ŠğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ğŸ”¥
posts.cooked:
amsignalling:

Maybe this could be a replacement for the PIN but that seems like a very complex thing to implement to replace something with as simple of a use case as with the PIN.

PINs can be phished. Passkeys cannot. And Passkeys are not that complicated to use. Itâ€™s actually simpler than even a Yubikey. And if someone phishes or guesses your PIN, thatâ€™s a problem. If someone gets the public half of your passkey, they effectively have nothing more than when they started, and you can change your Passkey if you want.

amsignalling:

I donâ€™t think Signal will ever implement a cloud backup option.

They already have, partially. When you register on a new device without a backup or data transfer, and provide your PIN, and you see things like your profile, group chat membership etc. populate, how do you think itâ€™s doing that? What do you think the Signal PIN is for otherwise?

From the Signal PIN FAQ:

Your Signal PIN is a numeric or alphanumeric code used to help you recover your profile, settings, contacts, and block list if you ever lose or switch devices. It supports features like non-phone number based identifiers. A PIN can also serve as a registration lock.

To enable PINs, Signal developed Secure Value Recovery which keeps your social graph unknown to Signal servers. This is unlike other apps and platforms that store this kind of data in plaintext on their servers.

I would consider using a hardware key instead of a PIN, though I donâ€™t see the urgency. Good password (PIN) practice should be enough in this case.

I would not want to use a phone-based nor account-based passkey with Signal. In each case, if the passkey store is breached, then access to Signal can be granted. In the case of a compromised phone, someone would be able to transfer my account to a new phone and prevent my ability to reclaim it by changing the passkey. In the case of a compromised Google or other account, the takeover could be done remotely.

I think that phone-based or account-based passkeys are fine in general. I just prefer more separation for accounts that handle importnant communication.

CueHD:

I would consider using a hardware key instead of a PIN

This would result in near-zero adoption.

posts.name: ğŸ‘ŠğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ğŸ”¥
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

I would consider using a hardware key instead of a PIN

Passkeys will obsolete TOTP and hardware keys. The hardware key is your phone with Passkeys.
It can replace them, I just donâ€™t want it to. TOTP is convenient enough. The hardware key is a backup. A hardware key kept in a secure location is a better backup than a phone I carry all the time.

I would have thought this unlikely given, even though theoretically it may meet the, â€˜something you know, something you have, something you areâ€™ trifecta of solid security.
Im pretty sure they didnt mean put all three of these things on a networked device that you only hold user privileges on, and the admin is a large corporate developer.
Passkeys are also backed up.

This is only true for account-based passkeys. I know that Google does this, so anyone using a â€œdeGoogled phoneâ€ will not have passkey backup potential. I donâ€™t know if or how Apple addresses this. Even for account-based passkeys, the actual passkey is still stored on and used from the device not the Google account.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.cooked:
CueHD:

This is only true for account-based passkeys

What do you mean by account-based passkeys?

QuickBanana:

What do you mean for account-based passkeys?

Passkeys that are stored and backed up using an online account.

The service that needs the passkey for authentication is not engaging with Google, only with whatever hardware has the passkey. Since Google controls the hardware, they are able to access the passkey (in encrypted form) and store it within your account. Then if you require the backup, Google will serve the encrypted passkey to your new device. You will only be able to decrypt it using the PIN/password that was used on your old device.

This is in contrast with passkeys that are generated or stored only on a single device such as a â€œdeGoogled phoneâ€, Yubikey, etc.

I believe that Apple also backs up passkeys for iPhones but I do not know the details.

I thought this article gives good context to â€œpasskeysâ€ and explains the distinction between hardware bound â€˜discoverable WebAuthn/FIDO credentialsâ€™ or â€œpasskeysâ€ and copyable (less phishing resistant) and therefore syncable non hardware bound passkeys.
Looks like passkeys will not be replacing your hardware keys Cue, your hardware key already has the ability to store these credentials and is considered the optimal solution for sensitive high risk situations.
